author: Nayonika Bose
title: After Team India’s T20 World Cup victory parade, BMC collects 11,500 kg waste from Mumbai’s Marine Drive
text:
From shoes and clothes to plastic bottles – a day after Mumbaikars gathered to celebrate the Indian Cricket Team winning the T20 World Cup, the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) collected 11,500 kg (11.5 metric tonne) on the side of the road. The speed of Marine Drive.
A BMC official said, “Due to the large number of people who have arrived in the area, sanitation services are disrupted in a short period of time. Even then, the drive was completed by 8 am, during which time, we removed and loaded the waste in one computer, one dumper and five SCBVs. “Most of the waste that was loaded into the small trucks was soft, which is heavy but not too heavy,” said a government official.
Driving at night
In an overnight drive, the civic body has mobilized 100 workers, including laborers, to ensure that the encroachments are cleared even before morning commuters arrive on Friday.
When the victory-victory came to an end and the sea of ​​fans entered the river of a few, the Marine Drive stadiums were left with garbage ranging from plastic bottles, chip papers, cups, papers, clothes and even shoes and boots. chappals, which several guests lost in the commotion of the panic-stricken crowd. (Source: Express Photos/ BMC)
Bringing life to a standstill in the biggest city on Thursday night, many fans flocked to see the “Men in Blue” group that took place on a 1.7 kilometer long journey from the National Center for Performing Arts (NCPA) to the Wankhede Stadium. Packed like sardines, thousands thronged the Wankhade Stadium to cheer on their heroes, as well as the T20 World Cup trophy, which arrived at the stadium around 8.30 pm.
What the fans left behind
When the victory-victory came to an end and the sea of ​​fans entered the stream of a few, the Marine Drive stadiums were left with garbage ranging from plastic bottles, chip papers, cups, papers, clothes and even shoes and boots. chappals, which several guests lost in the commotion of the panic-stricken crowd.
Without wasting time, at 11.30 pm on Thursday, the BMC sent around 100 workers from the waste management department who started their cleanliness drive. The development agency also hired 25 workers through non-governmental organizations, which helped with the operation.
Dumper, compactor, five small trucks and 11.5 MT garbage
Working through the night, government workers picked up two trucks – one dumper and one computer – containing more than nine pieces of garbage. According to a BMC official, the capacity of one dumper is three metric tons and one compactor holds six tons of waste.
In addition to this, the development agency also filled five small closed vans (SCBV) with odd items like shoes, chappals and other recyclables, which were later dropped at Suraksha Garden. Each SCBV has a holding capacity of 500 kg. The cleanup was completed by 8am on Friday.
Several citizens who flocked to Marine Drive on their morning commute took to social media to praise the government workers for clearing the garbage overnight. (Source: Express Photos/ BMC)
According to the community organization, five small jeeps containing reusable items such as shoes and slippers will be sent for recycling.
Netizens appreciate BMC's efforts
Several citizens who flocked to Marine Drive on their morning commute took to social media to praise the government workers for clearing the garbage overnight.
User X, @ivaibhavk, shared a video and wrote, “Thank you to the sanitation workers of the Mumbai Municipal Corporation. Before the citizens who celebrated the World Cup victory woke up, the sanitation workers had already cleaned and repaired the area of ​​Marine Drive. Last night, the area of Marine Drive was littered with thousands of shoes, and these workers were busy clearing away the debris. By morning, they had restored Mumbai to its original state. We all have to thank these workers, one for the night and one for the morning .
Many thanks to the sanitation workers of the Mumbai Municipal Corporation.
